newsitem.title: UK: Britain's Major renews TV election debate challenge.
newsitem.headline: Britain's Major renews TV election debate challenge.

text.p: British Prime Minister John Major said on Tuesday he remained ready to hold a television election debate with opposition chief Tony Blair, and accused the Labour leader of being "chicken" in backing away from the challenge.
"We the Conservative Party have accepted the terms of the broadcasters' proposals as they stand even though they are not perfect from our point of view," Major told a campaign news conference.
Stealing a Labour slogan for the May 1 general election, Major said: "This country does deserve better, it deserves a Labour Party and a Labour leader that can discuss the issues.
"Turkeys may not vote for Christmas, but chickens apparently run away from broadcasters."
Labour said last Thursday that it regarded current negotiations on the format of a televised debate between the two leaders as "at an end" and accused the Conservatives of being inflexible.

With Labour a good 20 points ahead in the polls, political commentators believe Blair has little to win from a debate, which would be the first in British electoral history, while Major has nothing to lose.
